Author: B. G√ºltekin √áetiner#0626
Content: What do you mean by global address? Is it blockchain fund in third layer? If it can be spent from there it is best solution. We need to start the chain with ac_perc. This is actually what we discussed. If we can spend from the blockchain fund it will solve the problem. Suppose I am a holder/issuer/endorser, I have enough activated or boosted but not enough normal to cover small fee. This should be spendable from the blockchain fund. Then this blockchain fund may be used for transferring baton to issuer as well. Is it difficult or impossible technically?

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
The 'global address' is a feature common for every komodo cc contract. This address might be used for various purposes. It is like a shared account. Although anyone might spend funds from this address this spending is controlled by the validation code.
Currently in marmara this address is used for storage of markers, that is, small amounts on this address which allow to enumerate the transactions which have such an utxo. By this we can find all 'marmaraissue' transactions for open credit loops.
The marmara validation code will allow to spend such markers for the settlement transactions and by this close the credit loop.
And yes we can store marmara's backup fund on this adddress too.

Author: B. G√ºltekin √áetiner#0626
Content: Can we start a new test chain such as MCL1 with the common blockchain fund? This is stated in requirements document as the third layer for protection against nonredemption. In case of insufficient normal funds but with enough activated/boosted, this fund may be utilized. Perhaps It may be utilized for transferring baton to issuer at the end when the credit loop expires.

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
Yes I think we can a new chain which would allow to use common fund to cover normal accounts with insufficient amounts on them.
To allow a miner to transfer the baton we should change the way of baton's storage: now the baton is on the holder's pubkey and no one except him can move the baton. To allow a miner to move it we should store the baton on some special address (like 1of2 address of endorser pk+global pk) which would allow both endorser and miner to move the baton. Plus we will need to write very carefully the validation code to prevent moving the baton in all cases except the settlement.

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
But from the previous messages I understood we may avoid returning the baton to the issuer after the settlement. How will it be used after it is returned to the issuer?
If we can avoid it I'd suggest maybe not to change this. It seems to me the storing the baton on the loop participant's pubkey is simple solution and does not involve additional transaction validation

Author: B. G√ºltekin √áetiner#0626
Content: Which one is easier and more efficient? You don‚Äôt need to change if it is easier to avoid transferring. Please feel free on that. But can we still use the idea of common fund to cover insufficient normal accounts with enough activated/boosted during settlement?

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
I'd say this is not about which one is easier. It is more like what is needed. I noticed in the chat messages that we are going to use moving the baton back to the issuer to indicate that the loop is closed. But we also have another feature for the same task - the marker. We already do spending the marker at the settlement to closed the loop. Maybe this will solve that task. 
But if not, and we need to move the baton to the issuer for some other reasons, let's do this.

Yes the common fund feature will be implemented, I cannot see any problems to do this.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i suggest not changing the baton handling, it serves no purpose other than to match the spec. it is much easier and safer to change the spec on this detail

Content: Ok. Please let us not transfer the baton back to issuer. A marker/flag is enough to show whether a loop is closed/settled. I will change the specification in document.

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
I have made a version with a special test parameter -marmara-test-pubkey where generated activated coins are sent to (in the repo).
To test staking multipliers I suggest preparing for the test 2 PoS nodes and 2 non-mining nodes.
On the 1st PoS node set up a credit loop for some amount (and lock all activated coins)
On the 2nd PoS node provide the same amount of activated coins (and no lock-in-loop)
On both the PoS nodes set -marmara-test-pubkey to pubkeys from the 2 non-mining nodes correspondingly.
on those non-mining nodes you will be able to see generated coins for staked utxos with 1x and 3x multipliers

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: you could see generated results on the 2 non-mining nodes with marmarainfo rpc

Author: Paro#7842

Author: Paro#7842
Content: what should we do.

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
The idea is to have a test environment providing results that are easy to check.
The test should show that lock-in-loop coins provide 3x chances for staking vs 1x for activated coins.
To check this it will be good if there are 2 staking nodes in the test, one with activated coins and another with lock-in-loop coins.
Both amounts should be equal, to make it possible to check the ratio easy.

As PoS nodes generate new activated coins they would interfere with initially set coins for staking.
That's why a temp parameter was added to komodod to send generated coins to other addresses.
so we could send them to any 2 non-mining nodes (for example pk1 and pk2)

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
so we should have 2 PoS nodes (setgenerate=0), on the first of them let's set up 500 activated coins and for the 2nd node 500 lock-in-loop 
Credit period should be long enough, for example 24 hours 
on both nodes we need add temp params:
-marmara-test-pubkey=pk1
-marmara-test-pubkey=pk2
and we could monitor generated coins on the pk1 and pk2 nodes with marmarainfo (and check the ratio)

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
I'm trying to do staking test (with the environment I suggested: 2 PoS nodes, 1 PoW node and 2 mining node to receive coinbase rewards).
For now results are not satisfactory: generated coins are not distributed in the expected ratio, the deviation is very big.
I am now investigating what is wrong...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the percentages will take a few thousand blocks to stabilize

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless you are comparing 10%+ stakes against each other, it could take much longer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: do you have 10% of coin supply staking in each of the test cases?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and how many blocks before you determine something is wrong?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if the math is correct and the 3x increase is comparing against hashes divided by three, then over time, it will end up at 3x.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe for testing the 3x should be increased to 30x to exaggerate the effect

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: however pos64 has segments to reduce the staking advantage of a whale address and that also can affect things

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
My environment is following:
I have 2 PoS nodes and have on both the pubkeys by 186 coins (as activated coins)
The total supply is 100,000 and most of this amount is on the first pk as normal. I thought it was not relevant as only activated or locked-in-loop coins participate in staking.
My test chain is 333 blocks now
Actually as a first test I tried to set equal amount of activated coins on both the PoS nodes and expected to have approximately equal amounts of coinbase rewards. I waited for 30 blocks and saw that only 3 of them went to the second node rewards, the rest of them went to the first node.

I did not do coins distribution on 64 segids (as this is not implemented yet for marmara activated coins) - maybe this is the cause. If it is, it needs to be implemented first and then continue the test

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can negate the effect of segids by putting both test addresses in the same segid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then the segid differences wont matter

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at 100,000 total coins and 333 blocks, it is not yet converged to the average blocktime and in the process of diff adjusting

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the variance will be MUCH greater

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 186 / 100000 coins is WAY too small to get a meaningfully accurate result, you would need a week or a month

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: put in 40,000 coins in each address, from same segid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then in a day you should see things converge

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it also depends on the power of PoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: many, many factors

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
Ok, thank you very much, I'll try all this.
(maybe the staking code iterates segids and not randomizes them and might be just picking the earliest one)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: staking code has logic to pick the utxo that can win a block the earliest

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: regardless of all the other factors

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are basically trying to tell apart 0.1% from 0.3%

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with 300 samples

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: during the time where the overall block generation is still calibrating itself relative to PoW strength and coins staking

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 33% of the time the 0.1% will get a block before the 0.3% and then now it has more utxo that is able to stake
